title: Drawing, "Textile Design, Petunias, Honeysuckle, and Berries", 1897–1898
medium: Brush and watercolor, graphite on dark cream wove paper
provenance: C.G. Forrer, Paris; Forrer Heirs, Paris; Barlach Heuer, Paris; Galerie Brockstedt, Hamburg; Frederick Mulder, London; Aimee Troyen, London and New York (October 1983)
description: Printed textile design with hollyhocks in foreground, a "C"-shaped honeysuckle vine curving around the hollyhocks from lower right to upper left, and  a meandering abstract design in monochrome in the background.
justification:
While textile designs were not a major part of his graphic production, Mucha produced a number of designs for printed fabrics between 1897 and 1898 (as recorded in the artist's diaries).&nbsp; All of these were handled by the firm of Carl Gustave Forrer (b.1852), an industrial draftsman of Swiss origin established in Paris at 40, rue des Jeuneurs and in Sannois, 190 rue de Paris.&nbsp; The Forrer firm sent the designs&nbsp;to an Alsatian printing firm, Sheurer, Lauth & Cie and possibly a London shop for manufacture.&nbsp; It is not clear how many of Mucha's designs were actually produced or how they were used.&nbsp; Comparatively few printed textiles are known today.&nbsp; Examples may be found in the Victoria and Albert Museum, London, the Württemberigisches Landesmuseum, Stuttgart, and at Cooper-Hewitt.
In describing Mucha’s textile designs generally, the designer Maurice Pillard Verneuil&nbsp; (1869-1942) said&nbsp;“His system of composition is two-part in the sense that in the same design, he combines a very stylized design with one very close to nature.&nbsp; A very naturalistic floral design occupies the first plane and in the background, a simple stylized form completes the ensemble.”&nbsp; (“Adaptation du Décor à la Forme,” in Art et Décoration, 1903).&nbsp; This comment aptly applies to the proposed design.
